<bibl default="NO">16, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam bibit avide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:59" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pransus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:127 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 127 al.</bibl></cit>— <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">avidius se in voluptates mergere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:18:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 18, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">procurrere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:15:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 15, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">avidius vino ciboque corpora onerant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 41, 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vesci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:18" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 18</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">avidissime exspectare aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:14:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 14, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">credere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 1, 1, § 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adprehendere palmam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 14, 22, 28, § 147</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
avienus: <entryFree id="n4712" type="main" key="A^vi^e_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăvĭēnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>: Rufus Festus Avienus, <sense id="n4712.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman poet in the last half of the fourth century</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whose most distinguished work is a</hi> Metaphrasis Periegesos Dionysii, <hi rend="ital">and a metaphrase of the Phœnomena of Aratus;</hi> cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. pp. 128 sq. and 153; Teuffel. Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 413.</sense></entryFree>
avipes: <entryFree id="n4713" type="main" key="a^vi^pe_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvĭ-pēs</orth>, <itype>pĕdis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>avis</etym>, <sense id="n4713.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">bird-footed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">swift-footed</hi>: avipedis animula leporis, Serenus ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 5, § 518</bibl> (also in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1518,001:page=2415" default="NO"><author>Ter. Maur.</author> p. 2415</bibl> P., and in Mar. Vict. pp. 2546 and 2595 P.).</sense></entryFree>
avis: <entryFree id="n4714" type="main" key="a^vis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (<sense id="n4714.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abl. sing.</hi> avi and ave; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:section=66" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, § 66</bibl> Müll.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 765</bibl> P.; Rhem. Palaem. p. 1374 P.; Neue, Formenl. I. pp. 218, 222; in the lang. of religion, the form avi is most common; <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>) [cf. Sanscr. vā (which may imply av), to blow <cb n="AVIU" /> (to wave); vis, a bird; Zend, vi; with which Curt. compares <foreign lang="greek">oi)-wno/s</foreign>, a large bird, and Benfey <foreign lang="greek">ai)-eto/s</foreign>, an eagle]. </sense><sense id="n4714.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a bird;</hi> or collect., <hi rend="ital">the winged tribe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Liber captivos avis ferae consimilis est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 1, 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">videmus novis avibus canere undique silvas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:256" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 256</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arguta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:18:30" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 18, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">istā enim avi (sc. aquilā) volat nulla vehementius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:70:144" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 70, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ave ad perfugia litorum tendente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 3, 3, § 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Deut. 4, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:4:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 4, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:13:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 13, 34</bibl> et saep.—In Varr. once of bees: <cit><quote lang="la">de incredibili earum avium naturā audi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16, 3</bibl></cit>.—A description of birds is found ap. Plin. l<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:10" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 10</bibl>; of their habits, ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:3 sq" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 3 sq.</bibl> and ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:1 sq" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 1 sq.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4714.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4714.3" n="A" level="2"> Esp., in reference to auguries, since the Romans took their omens or auguries from birds (v. augurium and auspicium): post quam avem aspexit templo Anchises, Naev. ap. Prob. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 31</bibl>.—Hence, avis, meton., = omen <hi rend="ital">a sign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">omen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">portent</hi>, freq. with the epithets bona, mala, sinistra ( = bona; <cit><quote lang="la">v. sinister), adversa, etc.: liquido exeo foras Auspicio avi sinistrā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ducam legiones meas Avi sinistrā, auspicio liquido atque ex sententiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:4:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 2, 4, 72</bibl></cit>: solvere secundo rumore aversāque avi, poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:16:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 16, 29</bibl>, where B. and K. read <hi rend="ital">adversā</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">malā ducis avi domum,</quote> <trans><tr>with a bad omen</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:15:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 15, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">este bonis avibus visi natoque mihique,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:513" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 513</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:640" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 15, 640</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">di, qui secundis avibus in proelium miserint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:12:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 12, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quā ego hunc amorem mihi esse avi dicam datum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 3, 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hac veniat natalis avi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:2:21" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 2, 21</bibl></cit>.—In <case>abl.</case>, form ave: <cit><quote lang="la">tunc ave deceptus falsā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 147</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4714.4" n="B" level="2"> Comically, for a man in the garb of a bird: <cit><quote lang="la">Sed quae nam illaec est avis, quae huc cum tunicis advenit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 2, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4714.5" n="C" level="2"> Avis alba, v. albus, I. B. 3. e.</sense></entryFree>
avite: <entryFree id="n4715" type="main" key="a^vi_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvītē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. avitus <sense id="n4715.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
avitium: <entryFree id="n4716" type="hapax" key="a^vi^ti^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvĭtĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>avis</etym>, <sense id="n4716.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the winged race</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tam pulcra ales, quae ex omni avitio longe praecellit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> de Deo Socr. prol. p. 186</bibl></cit> Hildebrand.</sense></entryFree>
avitus: <entryFree id="n4717" type="main" key="a^vi_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>avus</etym>, <sense id="n4717.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a grandfather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coming from a grandfather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ancestral.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4717.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">paternae atque avitae possessiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:30:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 30, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bona paterna et avita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:14:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 14, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res patrita et avita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 5, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">patrita illa et avita philosophia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:19:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 19, 45</bibl></cit>: avitus ac patritus mos, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 161, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">leges avitae et patritae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hospitium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">divitiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:68:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 68, 121</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (pallium, sudarium etc.) palam soles habere tamquam avita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:25:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 25, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">solium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:169" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 169</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:650" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 650</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">fundus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:12:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 12, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cellae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 37, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regnum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 8, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sanguis, Prep. 3, 19, 37: nomen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:239" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 239</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">umbrae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> F.1, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nobilitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 35, 58, § 117</bibl></cit> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n4717.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> to animals: <cit><quote lang="la">asinus fortitudinem celeritatemque avitam refert,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:37:4" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 37, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">color,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:37:4:section=7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 37, 4, § 7</bibl></cit>.—In gen., <hi rend="ital">very old</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ancient</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">merum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:695" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 2, 695</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi> not found; cf. Neue, Formenl. II. p. 230.—* <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvītë</orth>;,  <hi rend="ital">from ancient times</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 39</bibl> dub.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4718" type="main" key="A^vi_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăvītus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4718.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman</hi> cognomen: <cit><quote lang="la">A. Cluentius Avitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 5, 11</bibl></cit> sqq.</sense></entryFree>
avius: <entryFree id="n4719" type="main" key="a_vi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā-vĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>via</etym>, <sense id="n4719.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that is out of the way</hi>, <hi rend="ital">remote</hi>, <hi rend="ital">out of the right way;</hi> also, <hi rend="ital">untrodden</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfrequented</hi>, <hi rend="ital">solitary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lonely</hi>, etc. (while <hi rend="ital">devius</hi> signifies leading from the right way; and <hi rend="ital">invius</hi>, having no way, pathless; in the poets and histt. freq.). </sense><sense id="n4719.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4719.2" n="A" level="2"> Silvani lucus extra murum est avius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 4, 6, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Avia Pieridum peragro loca, nullius ante Trita solo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:926" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 926</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemora avia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 145</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virgulta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:328" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 328</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">montes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:23:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 23, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aviis itineribus,</quote> <trans><tr>through by-ways</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 54:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 54, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus (Caesaris) sibi species itinere avio occurrisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:96" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">solitudines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:55" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">avia commeatibus loca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:19:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 19, 16</bibl></cit>.—Also, </sense><sense id="n4719.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">āvĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a by-way</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a desert</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wilderness;</hi> in a pun with avium, from avis: hunc avium dulcedo ducit ad avium, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 21, 29</bibl>.—More freq. in <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">āvĭa</orth>, ōrum: <cit><quote lang="la">avia cursu Dum sequor, et notā excedo regione viarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:737" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 737</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per avia ac derupta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 21</bibl></cit>: per avia, Ov M. 1, 701; 2, 205.—So with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: avia <pb n="216" /> <cb n="AVUL" /> vinerum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:75" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 75</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 179</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saltuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2</bibl></cit>. 68: <cit><quote lang="la">Oceani,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Armeniae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 37</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4719.4" n="C" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of persons, <hi rend="ital">wandering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">straying</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Continuo in montes sese avius abdidit altos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:810" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 810</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4719.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Avius a verā longe ratione vagaris,</quote> <trans><tr>astray</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 82</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:229" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 229</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:740" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 740</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">3, 463: init nunc avia coepto Consilia,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>leading away from the undertaking</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:493" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 493</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
avocamentum: <entryFree id="n4720" type="main" key="a_vo^ca_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āvŏcāmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>avoco</etym>, <sense id="n4720.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a means of diverting from</hi> pain, trouble, etc., <hi rend="ital">an alleviation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">diversion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">relaxation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">recreation</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">omnia mihi avocamenta exemit dolor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:8:23:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 8, 23, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admittere avocamenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 8:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 5, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:82:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pan. 82, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 498</bibl>; Lact. Opif. Dei, 18; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> adv. Gent. 166</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
avocatio: <entryFree id="n4721" type="main" key="a_vo^ca_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āvŏcātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n4721.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a calling off from</hi> a thing, <hi rend="ital">a diverting of the attention</hi>, <hi rend="ital">diversion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">interruption</hi> (very rare): avocatio a cogitandā molestiā, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:15:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 15, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">In his, quae me sine avocatione circumstrepunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 56:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 56, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
avocator: <entryFree id="n4722" type="main" key="a_vo^ca_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āvŏcātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n4722.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that calls off</hi> or <hi rend="ital">away</hi> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Carn. Christ. 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
avocatrix: <entryFree id="n4723" type="main" key="a_vo^ca_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āvŏcātrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>avocator</etym>, <sense id="n4723.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">she that calls away</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">veritatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
avoco: <entryFree id="n4724" type="main" key="a_vo^co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā-vŏco</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (arch. <sense id="n4724.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, AVOCARIER, C. I. L. I. p. 198), <hi rend="ital">to call off</hi> or <hi rend="ital">away.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4724.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">partem exercitūs ad bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:61:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 61, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pubem in arcem praesidio armisque obtinendam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 6, 1</bibl></cit>: Consul ab omnibus magistratibus et comitiatum et contionem avocare potest. Messala ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:16:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 16, 1</bibl>.—With <case>dat.</case> (for ab aliquo): nec avocare alius alii posset, si contionem habere volunt, Messala ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:16:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 16, 1</bibl>.— <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">a rebus occultis avocare philosophiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 4, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut (orator) a propriis personis et temporibus avocet controversiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:14:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 14, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibusdam ad Antiochum multitudinis animos avocantibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 9, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4724.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n4724.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To call one off from</hi> an action, purpose, wish, etc., i. e. <hi rend="ital">to withdraw</hi>, <hi rend="ital">divert</hi>, <hi rend="ital">turn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">remove</hi>, <hi rend="ital">separate</hi> (the usual signif. of the word): <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem ab aliquā re voluptas avocat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 6, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si te laus adlicere ad recte faciendum non potest, ne metus quidem a foedissimis factis potest avocare?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem ab alicujus conjunctione,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos jam aetas a proeliis avocabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:32:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 32, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senectus avocat a rebus gerendis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:5:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 5, 15</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:26:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Balb. 26, 59</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui omnino avocent a philosophiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 1, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:4:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 4, 9</bibl> hos a bello avocas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 5, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">avocat a curā vocis ille adfectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:25" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:40" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 40</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4724.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To withdraw the attention</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to distract</hi>, <hi rend="ital">divert.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4724.5" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To withdraw</hi> by interrupting, <hi rend="ital">to interrupt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hinder</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">multum distringebar frigidis negotiis, quae simul et avocant animum et comminuunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:9:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 9, 2, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4724.6" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To divert</hi> by cheering, <hi rend="ital">to divert</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cheer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">amuse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab iis quae avocant abductus, et liber et mihi relictus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:9:36:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 9, 36, 2</bibl></cit>; hence, se, <hi rend="ital">to divert</hi>, <hi rend="ital">entertain one</hi>'<hi rend="ital">s self</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 7, p. 215</bibl>; and <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi> with mid. sense: illic avocare et illic lude, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:32:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 32, 15</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4724.7" n="C. 1." level="1"> In the Lat. of the jurists = revocare, <hi rend="ital">to reclaim</hi>, <hi rend="ital">recall</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">partem ejus, quod in fraudem datum esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:22:3:6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 22, 3, 6</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">possessionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19:1:3" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 19, 1, 3</bibl></cit>; also with <case>dat.</case> (for <hi rend="ital">ab aliquo</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">non potest avocari ei res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:35:2:1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 35, 2, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4724.8" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">factum,</quote> <trans><tr>to revoke</tr>, <tr>disavow</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:39:5:6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 39, 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arma,</quote> <trans><tr>to make a feint in fighting</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:1:20" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 1, 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
avolo: <entryFree id="n4725" type="main" key="a_vo^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā-vŏlo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n4725.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fly forth</hi> or <hi rend="ital">away</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per aetherias umbras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:66:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 66, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auspicanti pullos avolāsse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:18" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:41:1:5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 41, 1, 5</bibl>.—Hence, of persons, <hi rend="ital">to flee away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to go away quickly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hasten away</hi> (opp. advolare, to flee to): <cit><quote lang="la">experiar certe, ut hinc avolem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">avolat ipse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:712" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 712</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">citatis equls avolant Romam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:57:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 57, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:61:7" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 61, 7</bibl> (al. advolat).—So of dying: <cit><quote lang="la">Critoni non persuasi me hinc avolaturum,</quote> <trans><tr>that I shall flee from this world</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:43:103" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 43, 103</bibl></cit>.—Of the vanishing of pleasure: <cit><quote lang="la">Fluit voluptas corporis et prima quaequo avolat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:32:106" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 32, 106</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
avulsio: <entryFree id="n4726" type="main" key="a_vulsi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āvulsĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">āvol-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>avello</etym>; in gardening, t. t., <sense id="n4726.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plucking off</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tearing off of the branches of a tree</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aut semine (arbores) proveniunt aut plantis radicis aut propagine aut avolsione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 10, 9, § 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:98" default="NO" valid="yes">17, 13, 21, § 98</bibl>. <cb n="AXIS" /></sense></entryFree>
avulsor: <entryFree id="n4727" type="hapax" key="a_vulsor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āvulsor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">āvol-</orth>), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n4727.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that tears off</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi (spongeae) avolsorem sensere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 45, 69, § 148</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
avulsus: <entryFree id="n4728" type="main" key="a_vulsus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āvulsus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">āvolsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, v. avello.</entryFree>
avunculus: <entryFree id="n4729" type="main" key="a^vuncu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvuncŭlus</orth> (AVOMCVLVS and AVONCLVS, Fabr. Gloss. p. 227, a), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>avus; cf. Lith. avynas, uncle</etym>, <sense id="n4729.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mother</hi>'<hi rend="ital">s brother</hi>, <hi rend="ital">maternal uncle</hi> (a brother of the father, patruus). </sense><sense id="n4729.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4729.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:84:341" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 84, 341</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:343" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 343</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 8, 6, § 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:28:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 28, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">29, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">uxor patrui vel avunculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:20:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Lev. 20, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 9, 6, 17</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:10" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 10</bibl> P.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n4729.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n4729.4" n="1" level="3"> Avunculus magnus, <hi rend="ital">a grandmother</hi>'<hi rend="ital">s brother</hi> (aviae frater), <hi rend="ital">great-uncle</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:62:222" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 62, 222</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:10" default="NO">38, 10, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 9, 16, 26</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4729.5" n="2" level="3"> Avunculus major, <hi rend="ital">a brother of the great-grandmother</hi>, <hi rend="ital">greatgreat-uncle</hi> (proaviae frater), Dig. l. l. (in Isid. Orig. l. l., proavunculus).—</sense><sense id="n4729.6" n="3" level="3"> Avunculus maximus, <hi rend="ital">a brother of the great-greatgrandmother</hi> (abaviae frater), Dig. l. l. (in Isid. Orig. l. l., abavunculus).—In the histt. sometimes avunculus major = avunculus magnus, <hi rend="ital">brother of the grandmother</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:59" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 59</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 3</bibl>; and avunculus <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> = avunculus major, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 43</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 53</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 75</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4729.7" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the husband of the mother</hi>'<hi rend="ital">s sister</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Cons. ad Helv. 17" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Cons. ad Helv. 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
avus: <entryFree id="n4730" type="main" key="a^vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvus</orth> (AVS, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Fabr.</author> 389</bibl>, also <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăvŏs</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>kindr. with Goth. avo, grandmother; old Norse, afi, grandfather; cf. Heb. <foreign />, āb, father; Chald. <foreign />, <foreign lang="greek">a)bba=</foreign>; and Engl. abbot</etym>, <sense id="n4730.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a grandfather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grandsire.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4730.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">pater, avus, proavus, abavus, atavus, tritavus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 3, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:14:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 14, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 131</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 10, 6</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:10" default="NO">38, 10, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 9, 5, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 6, 23</bibl>.—Also transf. to animals (cf. 1. avitus, II.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:209" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 209</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4730.2" n="II" level="1"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n4730.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Ancestor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">forefather</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:30" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 16</bibl> (15), 174; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:491" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 9, 491</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">15, 425</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:8:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 4, 8, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:28:4 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 28, 4 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4730.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An old man</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0800,001:2:4" default="NO"><author>Albin.</author> 2, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
axamenta: <entryFree id="n4731" type="gloss" key="axa_menta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axāmenta</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>axis, II. F., since they were inscribed on tables of wood</etym>, <sense id="n4731.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">religious hymns written in Saturnian measure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which were annually sung by the Salii</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=3" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 3</bibl> Müll.: axamenta: <foreign lang="greek">sti/xoi e)pi\ qusiw=n (*hrakle/ous</foreign>, Gloss.; cf. Smith, Dict. Antiq. The beginning of such a Salian hymn (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=86" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 86</bibl> Müll.) runs thus: Divom éxta cánte, Dívom Dío súpplicante.</sense></entryFree>
axare: <entryFree id="n4732" type="gloss" key="axa_re"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axāre</orth>: nominare, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=8" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 8</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
axeagglomerati: <entryFree id="n4733" type="gloss" key="axe agglo^me^ra_ti"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axe agglŏmĕrāti</orth>: universi stan tes, id est cohortibus aut legionibus, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 25</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
axedo: <entryFree id="n4734" type="hapax" key="axe_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axēdo</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = axis, II. F., <sense id="n4734.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a board</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plank</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:Emp. 33" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> Emp. 33 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
axenus: <entryFree id="n4735" type="greek" key="Axe^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Axĕnus</orth>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/cenos</foreign> (inhospitable): Axenus Pontus, <sense id="n4735.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an earlier name of the</hi> Pontus Euxinus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:4:55 sq" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 4, 55 sq.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
axicia: <entryFree id="n4736" type="hapax" key="axi^ci^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axĭcĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>cf. ascia</etym>, <sense id="n4736.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a pair of shears</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 4, 4, 22</bibl> Fleck.</sense></entryFree>
axiculus: <entryFree id="n4737" type="main" key="axi^cu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axĭcŭlus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">assĭc-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>axis</etym>. <sense id="n4737.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A small axle-tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4737.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4737.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A pin</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 21</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4737.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A small beam</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pole</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:19:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 19, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4737.4" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A small board</hi> or <hi rend="ital">plank</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 21, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">16, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
axilla: <entryFree id="n4738" type="gloss" key="axilla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axilla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. ala.</entryFree>
axim: <entryFree id="n4739" type="main" key="axim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axim</orth>, axit = egerim, egerit, v. ago <sense id="n4739.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
axinomantia: <entryFree id="n4740" type="main" key="axi_no^manti_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axīnŏmantīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)cinomantei/a</foreign>, <sense id="n4740.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of divination from axes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 19, 34, § 142</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 2, 5, § 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
axioma: <entryFree id="n4741" type="greek" key="axi^o_ma"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axĭōma</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ci/wma</foreign>, <sense id="n4741.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a principle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">axiom</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Dogm. Plat. 3</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 8</bibl> (in pure Lat., proloquium, pronuntiatum, profatum, etc.; v. Gell. l. l.).</sense></entryFree>
axis: <entryFree id="n4742" type="main" key="axis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>kindred with Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)/cwn</foreign>; Sanscr. akshas = axle, wheel; old Germ. Ahsa; mod. Germ. Achse; Engl. axle, Bopp, Gloss. p. 2, a; cf. Aufrecht, Zeitschr. für vergl. Sprachf. 8, p. 71</etym>. <sense id="n4742.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an axletree</hi>, <hi rend="ital">about which a round body</hi>, e.g. <hi rend="ital">a wheel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">turns</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">faginus axis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:172" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 172</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">axes aerii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:7:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 7, 30</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">7, 33: axis versatilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:33:5 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eccli. 33, 5 al.</bibl></cit>—<usg type="style">Meton.</usg> (pars pro toto), <hi rend="ital">a chariot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">car</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wagon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 59</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:4:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 160</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 1442" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 1442</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:16:360 al" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 16, 360 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 148</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 634</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4742.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The axle of a water-clock</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 9, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The axis of the earth</hi>: mundum versari circum axem caeli, Cic. N. <cb n="AZYM" /> D. 1, 20, 52; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:Ac. 2:39:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 39, 123</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:Tim. 10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Tim. 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1107</bibl>.—Hence, meton. </sense><sense id="n4742.4" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The pole</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:7:422" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 7, 422</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">axis inocciduus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:175" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 175</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meridianus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 6, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.5" n="b" level="4"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">the north pole</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:720" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 720</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:28:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 28, 68</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:271" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 271</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 351</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:7:2" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 4, 7, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 4, 589</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.6" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The whole heavens</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">maximus Atlas Axem umero torquet stellis ardentibus aptum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:482" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 482</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 536</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:255" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 255</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 75</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 297</bibl>; 6, 175; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:2:46" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 1, 2, 46</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:86" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 86</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:3:3:76 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> S. 3, 3, 76 al.</bibl>—Hence, sub axe, <hi rend="ital">under the open heaven</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:512" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 512</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 28</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.7" n="d" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">A region of the heavens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a clime</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">boreus,</quote> <trans><tr>the north</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:8:41" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 8, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hesperius,</quote> <trans><tr>the west</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:214" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 4, 214</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:359" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 359</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.8" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A pin</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hook on which a hinge turns</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:346" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 346</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.9" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The valve of a pipe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.10" n="E" level="2"> Axes volutarum, in archit., <hi rend="ital">the axes of a volute</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4742.11" n="F" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A board</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plank</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 4, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:30:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 30, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 25, 62, § 187</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:455" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 455</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:12 al" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 12 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4742.12" n="G" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An unknown wild animal in India</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 21, 31, § 76</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
axites: <entryFree id="n4743" type="main" key="axi^tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axĭtes</orth> <itype>mulieres sive viri dicebantur unā agentes</itype>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=3" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 3</bibl> Müll. [ago].</entryFree>
axitiosus: <entryFree id="n4744" type="main" key="axi^ti^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axĭtĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n4744.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">acting together</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in combination; of a party</hi>: Axitiosae annonam caram e vili concinnant viris, Plaut. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=66" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 66</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">Mulier es, uxor—Cuja vis?—Ego novi: scio axitiosam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
axius: <entryFree id="n4745" type="main" key="Axi^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Axĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4745.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman</hi> nomen: <cit><quote lang="la">Q. Axius, a friend of Cicero's and Varro's,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 12, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:2:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:9" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:3:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 3, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4746" type="main" key="Axi^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Axĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">)/*acios</foreign>, <sense id="n4746.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Macedonia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">the Vardar</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:53:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 53, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:26:7" default="NO" valid="yes">44, 26, 7</bibl> and 8; 45, 29, 7 sq.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:1" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 10, 17, § 34</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
axon: <entryFree id="n4747" type="greek" key="axon1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/cwn</foreign>. <sense id="n4747.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A line upon the sundial</hi>, <hi rend="ital">its axis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 9, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4747.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A part of the</hi> ballista, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4747.2" n="III" level="1"> Axŏnes, um, <hi rend="ital">the laws of Solon engraved on tables of wood</hi> (axibus ligneis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 12</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. axis, II. F.),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 16, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4748" type="main" key="Axon2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Axon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4748.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in</hi> Caria, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 27, 29, § 103</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
axona: <entryFree id="n4749" type="main" key="Axo^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Axŏna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4749.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Gaul</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">the Aisne</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Mos. 461</bibl>; cf. Mann. Gall. 206.</sense></entryFree>
axungia: <entryFree id="n4750" type="main" key="axungi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">axungĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>axis-ungo</etym>, <sense id="n4750.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">axle-tree grease</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wagon grease.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4750.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:135" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 9, 37, § 135</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:156" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 10, 43, § 156</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n4750.2" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">grease</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fat</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 17, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 4, 10, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 12, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
axylos: <entryFree id="n4751" type="main" key="Axy^lo^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Axylŏs</orth> <itype>terra</itype> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)/culos</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n4751.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a poorly wooded region in</hi> Galatia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:18:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 18, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aza: <entryFree id="n4752" type="main" key="Aza"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aza</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4752.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in</hi> Armenia Minor, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 9, 10, § 26</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
azali: <entryFree id="n4753" type="main" key="Aza^li"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Azăli</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">)/*azaloi</foreign>, <sense id="n4753.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of</hi> Pannonia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 25, 28, § 148</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
azan: <entryFree id="n4754" type="main" key="Azan"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Azan</orth>, <itype>ānis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">)*aza/n</foreign>; <number>plur.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Azā-nes</orth>, <sense id="n4754.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in</hi> Arcadia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:292" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 292</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
azaniae: <entryFree id="n4755" type="greek" key="aza_ni^ae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">azānĭae</orth> <itype>nŭces</itype> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)za/nw</foreign>, to dry up</etym>, <sense id="n4755.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pine-nuts</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which open while yet on the tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 26, 44, § 107</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
azanius: <entryFree id="n4756" type="main" key="Aza_ni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Azānĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n4756.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Azanian</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a region in</hi> Aethiopia: <cit><quote lang="la">sinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 24, 28, § 108</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:153" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 153</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
azoni: <entryFree id="n4757" type="greek" key="azo_ni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">azōni</orth> <itype>di</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/zwnoi</foreign>, <sense id="n4757.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gods that possess no definite place in heaven</hi> (in pure Lat., communes), <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 12, 118</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 1, p. 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
azorus: <entryFree id="n4758" type="main" key="Azo_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Azōrus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">)/*azwros</foreign>, <sense id="n4758.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of Thessaly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at the foot of Mount Olympus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:2" default="NO" valid="yes">44, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
azotus: <entryFree id="n4759" type="main" key="Azo_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Azōtus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">)/*azwtos</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">)*azwto/s</foreign>, <sense id="n4759.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Palestine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near the coust</hi>, the <hi rend="ital">Ashdod</hi> of Holy Scripture, and now <hi rend="ital">Esdu/d</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:10" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 13, 14, § 68</bibl>; in Vulg., Asedoth, Jos. 10, 40; 12, 3.</sense></entryFree>
azymus: <entryFree id="n4760" type="greek" key="azy_mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">azȳmus</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">azymon</orth>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Apoth. 421</bibl>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/zumos</foreign>, <sense id="n4760.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">unleavened</hi> (very freq. in Vulg.). </sense><sense id="n4760.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4760.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">azymi panes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:12:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 12, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:6:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Jud. 6, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">panis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 133" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 133</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lagana azyma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 2, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,015:23:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Par. 23, 29</bibl>; and so <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">azȳma</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:12:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 12, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:8:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Lev. 8, 2 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4760.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., of the Jewish feast of unleavened bread: <cit><quote lang="la">dies festus azymorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:22:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 22, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dies azymorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:12:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 12, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">20, 6</bibl>; also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: Erat pascha et azyma (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">=\*hn to\ pa/sxa kai\ ta\ a)/zuma</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:14:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 14, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4760.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">unleavened</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">morally uncorrupted</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sicut estis azymi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Cor. 5, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in azymis sinceritatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 5, 8</bibl></cit>. <pb n="217" /> <cb n="B" /> <cb n="B." /></sense></entryFree>
b: <entryFree id="n4761" type="main" key="B"><orth extent="full" lang="la">B</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">b</orth>, <itype>indecl.</itype> <gen>n.</gen>, designates, in the Latin alphabet, the soft, labial sound as in English, unlike the Gr. beta (B, <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>), which approached the Engl. <sense id="n4761.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v</hi> in sound; v. Corss. Ausspr. I. p. 124 sqq. At the beginning of words it represents an original <hi rend="ital">dv</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gv</hi>, and elsewhere an original <hi rend="ital">gv</hi>, <hi rend="ital">p</hi>, <hi rend="ital">v</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">bh</hi> (<hi rend="ital">v</hi>); v. Corss. Ausspr. I. pp. 134, 161. It corresponds regularly with Gr. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, but freq. also with <foreign lang="greek">p</foreign>, and, in the middle of words, with <foreign lang="greek">f</foreign>; cf. brevis, <foreign lang="greek">braxu/s</foreign>; ab, <foreign lang="greek">a)po/</foreign>; carbasus, <foreign lang="greek">ka/rpasos</foreign>; ambo, <foreign lang="greek">a)mfi/, a)/mfw</foreign>; nubes, <foreign lang="greek">ne/fos</foreign>, etc.; v. Roby, Gram. I. p. 26; Kühner, Gram. § 34, 6. In Latin, as in all kindred languages, it was used in forming words to express the cry of different animals, as balare, barrire, baubari, blacterare, boare, bombitare, bubere, bubulare; children beginning to talk called their drink bua; so, balbus denoted the stammering sound, bambalio the stuttering, blatire and blaterare the babbling, blaesus the lisping, blandus the caressing. At the beginning of words <hi rend="ital">b</hi> is found with no consonants except <hi rend="ital">l</hi> and <hi rend="ital">r</hi> (for bdellium, instead of which Marc. Emp. also wrote bdella, is a foreign word); but in the middle of words it is connected with other liquid and feeble consonants. Before hard consonants <hi rend="ital">b</hi> is found only in compounds with <hi rend="ital">ob</hi> and <hi rend="ital">sub</hi>, the only prepositions, besides <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>, which end in a labial sound; and these freq. rejected the labial, even when they are separated by the insertion of <hi rend="ital">s</hi>, as abspello and absporto pass into aspello and asporto; or the place of the labial is supplied by <hi rend="ital">u</hi>, as in aufero and aufugio (cf. ab <hi rend="ital">init.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">au</hi>); before <hi rend="ital">f</hi> and <hi rend="ital">p</hi> it is assimilated, as suffero, suppono; before <hi rend="ital">m</hi> assimilated or not, as summergo or submergo; before <hi rend="ital">c</hi> sometimes assimilated, as succedo, succingo, sometimes taking the form <hi rend="ital">sus</hi> (as if from subs; cf. abs), as suscenseo; and sometimes <hi rend="ital">su</hi> before <hi rend="ital">s</hi> followed by a consonant, as suspicor. When <hi rend="ital">b</hi> belonged to the root of a word it seems to have been retained, as plebs from plebis, urbs from urbis, etc.; so in Arabs, chalybs ( = <foreign lang="greek">)/*aray, xa/luy</foreign>), the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">y</foreign> was represented by <hi rend="ital">bs;</hi> as also in absis, absinthi-um, etc. But in scripsi from scribo, nupsi from nubo, etc., <hi rend="ital">b</hi> was changed to <hi rend="ital">p</hi>, though some grammarians still wrote <hi rend="ital">bs</hi> in these words; cf. Prisc. pp. 556, 557 P.; Vel. Long. pp. 2224, 2261 ib. Of the liquids, <hi rend="ital">l</hi> and <hi rend="ital">r</hi> stand either before or after <hi rend="ital">b</hi>, but <hi rend="ital">m</hi> only before it, with the exception of abmatertera, parallel with the equally anomalous abpatruus (cf. ab <hi rend="ital">init.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>), and <hi rend="ital">n</hi> only after it; hence <hi rend="ital">con</hi> and <hi rend="ital">in</hi> before <hi rend="ital">b</hi> always become <hi rend="ital">com</hi> and <hi rend="ital">im;</hi> as inversely <hi rend="ital">b</hi> before <hi rend="ital">n</hi> is sometimes changed to <hi rend="ital">m</hi>, as Samnium for Sabinium and scamnum for scabnum, whence the dim. scabellum. <hi rend="ital">B</hi> is so readily joined with <hi rend="ital">u</hi> that not only acubus, arcubus, etc., were written for acibus, arcibus, etc., but also contubernium was formed from taberna, and bubile was used for bovile, as also in dubius ( = <foreign lang="greek">doio/s</foreign>, duo) a <hi rend="ital">b</hi> was inserted. <hi rend="ital">B</hi> could be doubled, as appears not only from the foreign words abbas and sabbatum, but also from obba and gibba, and the compounds with ob and sub. <hi rend="ital">B</hi> is reduplicated in bibo (cf the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">pi/w</foreign>), as the shortness of the first syllable in the preterit bĭbi, compared with dēdi and stĕti or sti/ti, shows; although later bibo was treated as a primitive, and the supine bibitum formed from it. Sometimes before <hi rend="ital">b</hi> an <hi rend="ital">m</hi> was inserted, e. g. in cumbo for cubo <foreign lang="greek">ku/ptw</foreign>, lambo for <foreign lang="greek">la/ptw</foreign>, nimbus for <foreign lang="greek">ne/fos</foreign>; inversely, also, it was rejected in sabucus for sambucus and labdacismus for lambdacismus. As in the middle, so at the beginning of words, <hi rend="ital">b</hi> might take the place of another labial, e. g. buxis for pyxis, balaena for <foreign lang="greek">fa/laina</foreign>, carbatina for carpatina, publicus from poplicus, ambo for <foreign lang="greek">a)/mfw</foreign>; as even Enn. wrote Burrus and Bruges for Pyrrhus and Phryges; Naev., Balantium for Palatium (v. the latter words, and cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=26" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 26</bibl>).—In a later age, but not often before A.D. 300, intercourse with the Greeks caused the pronunciation of the <hi rend="ital">b</hi> and <hi rend="ital">v</hi> to be so similar that Adamantius Martyrius in Cassiod. pp. 2295-2310 P., drew up a separate catalogue of words which might be written with either <cb n="BABY" /> <hi rend="ital">b</hi> or <hi rend="ital">v.</hi> So, Petronius has berbex for verbex, and in inscrr., but not often before A. D. 300, such errors as bixit for vixit, abe for ave, ababus for abavus, etc. (as inversely vene, devitum, acervus, vasis instead of bene, debitum, acerbus, basis), are found; Flabio, Jubentius, for Flavio, Juventius, are rare cases from the second century after Christ.—The interchange between labials, palatals, and linguals (as glans for <foreign lang="greek">ba/lanos</foreign>, bilis for fel or <foreign lang="greek">xolh/</foreign>) is rare at the beginning of words, but more freq. in the middle; cf. tabeo, <foreign lang="greek">th/kw</foreign>, and Sanscr. tak, terebra and <foreign lang="greek">te/retron</foreign>, uber and <foreign lang="greek">ou)=qar</foreign>; besides which the change of tribus Sucusana into Suburana (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=48" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 48</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:7:29" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 7, 29</bibl>) deserves consideration. This interchange is most freq. in terminations used in forming words, as ber, cer, ter; brum or bulum, crum or culum, trum, bundus and cundus; bilis and tilis, etc.—Finally, the interchange of <hi rend="ital">b</hi> with <hi rend="ital">du</hi> at the beginning of words deserves special mention, as duonus for bonus, Bellona for Duellona, bellum for duellum, bellicus for duellicus, etc., and bis from duis.—As an abbreviation, B usually designates bonus or bene. Thus, B. D. = Bona Dea, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1524</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2427</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2822</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">B. M. = bene merenti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 99</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">114</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">506</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">B. M. P. = bene merenti posuit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 255</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">B. D. S. M. = bene de se meritae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2437</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">B. V. V. = bene vale valeque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 4816</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">B. M. = bonae memoriae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1136</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3385</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">B. M. = bonā mente,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 5033</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">sometimes it stands for beneficiarius, and BB. beneficiarii,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3489</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3868</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3486 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
baal: <entryFree id="n4762" type="main" key="Ba_^al"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Bā^al</orth>, <gen>m.</gen>, <itype>indecl.</itype> <foreign /> (lord), <sense id="n4762.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Syrian deity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Bāal,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Apoth. 393</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Băal,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sedul.</author> 5, 147</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:18:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 18, 19</bibl> sqq.</sense></entryFree>
babae: <entryFree id="n4763" type="greek" key="ba^bae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">băbae</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">păpae</orth>, <pos>interj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">babai/</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">papai/</foreign>, an exclamation of wonder and joy, <sense id="n4763.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">odds bodkins! wonderful! strange!</hi> </sense><sense id="n4763.1" n="I" level="1"> Form babae: <cit><quote lang="la">huic babae! basilice te intulisti et facete,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:5:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 5, 2, 25</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 131</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 5, 2, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 52</bibl>; v. under II.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 37, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4763.2" n="II" level="1"> Form papae: <hi rend="ital">Ep.</hi> Cadum tibi veteris vini propino. <hi rend="ital">St.</hi> Papae! <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 3, 1, 24</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 7, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:5:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 5, 2, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 2, 2, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 5, 20</bibl>; Ter Eun. 2, 1, 23; 2, 2, 48; 3, 1, 26.</sense></entryFree>
babba: <entryFree id="n4764" type="main" key="Babba"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Babba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4764.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Mauritania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">called</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as a Roman colony</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Julia Campestris</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 1, 1, § 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
babel: <entryFree id="n4765" type="main" key="Babel"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Babel</orth>, <itype>ēlis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4765.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the capital city of Assyria</hi>, Aug. Civ. Dei, 16, 3, 11; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:11:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 11, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
babia: <entryFree id="n4766" type="main" key="Babi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Babĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4766.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of Lower Italy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 6, 8, § 69</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
babilus: <entryFree id="n4767" type="main" key="Babilus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Babilus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4767.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an astronomer of the time of Nero</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:36" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
babullius: <entryFree id="n4768" type="main" key="Babulli^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Babullĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4768.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rich friend of Cœsar</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:48:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 48, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
babulus: <entryFree id="n4769" type="main" key="babu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">babŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4769.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a babbler</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fool</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M 4, p. 149, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
baburrus: <entryFree id="n4770" type="gloss" key="baburrus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">baburrus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n4770.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">foolish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">silly</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 10, 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
babylo: <entryFree id="n4771" type="hapax" key="Ba^by^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (prob. from Babylon, a Babylonian, foreigner), <sense id="n4771.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a slave</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 7, 17</bibl> (acc. to others, <hi rend="ital">a man of Oriental wealth and luxury</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a nabob;</hi> cf. Bentl. ad loc.).</sense></entryFree>
babylon: <entryFree id="n4772" type="main" key="Ba^by^lo_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (<sense id="n4772.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> Gr. Babylonos, <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> IV. Cons. Hon. 653</bibl>; <case>acc.</case> Gr. Babylona, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3</bibl> (4), 11, 21; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:76" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 76</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:26:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 26, 30</bibl>, §§ 120 and 124), = <foreign lang="greek">*babulw/n</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Babylon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the ancient and renowned chief city of Babylonia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on both sides of the Euphrates</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whose ruins are found at Hille</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Irak Arabi</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:11:2" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 11, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:121 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 26, 30, § 121 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:6:9" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:23:47" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 23, 47</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 67, 139</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:4:27" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 4, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:8:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 8, 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:10:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 10, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4772.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n4772.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylō-nĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*babulwni/a</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n4772.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The Syrian province</hi>, <hi rend="ital">named after its capital</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Babylon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between the Euphrates and Tigris</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Babylonia;</hi> in a more extended sense, sometimes used for <hi rend="ital">all Syria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Assyria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and Mesopotamia;</hi> now <hi rend="ital">Irak Arabi</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:11:1" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 11, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 26, 30, § 117</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:1:43" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 1, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:3:17" default="NO">8, 3, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:20:4:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 20, 4, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,023:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Macc. 6, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4772.4" n="2" level="3"> For Babylon, <hi rend="ital">the city Babylon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:2:7" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 1, 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:13:6" default="NO">12, 13, 6</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:17:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 17, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 26, 30, § 122</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:6:20" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 6, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4772.5" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylōnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Babylonian</hi> (pertaining as well to the city Babylon as to Babylonia): <cit><quote lang="la">miles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 5, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Euphrates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:248" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 248</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">moenia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arx,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:1:25" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 1, 25</bibl></cit>: Seleucia,<cb n="BACC" />  <hi rend="ital">situated in Babylonia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:27:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 27, 31</bibl>, §§ <cit><quote lang="la">129 and 133: juncus (produced in the region of Babylon, of particular excellence),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 18, 72, § 120</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylōnĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Babylonians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:46" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 46</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:1:25" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 1, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:1:38" default="NO">5, 1, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:13:4:23" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 13, 4, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,014:17:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 4 Reg. 17, 30</bibl> al.—</sense><sense id="n4772.6" n="2" level="3"> In <hi rend="ital">fem. sing.</hi> Babylonia, <hi rend="ital">a Babylonian woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 44</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 99</bibl>.—And, since Babylonia was the primitive seat of astronomy and astrology, Babylonii numeri, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:11:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 11, 2</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:47" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 47</bibl>. 98: Chaldaicae rationes); and appel. for <hi rend="ital">skilled in astronomy and astrology</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">me creat Archytae suboles Babylonius Horops,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 1, 77.—</sense><sense id="n4772.7" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylōnĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = Babylonius, <hi rend="ital">Babylonian</hi>: peristromata (skilfully woven and inwrought with figures; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 48, 74, § 196</bibl>); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 2, 53</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">picta superbe texta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:8:28:17" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 8, 28, 17</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylōnĭca</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype> (more rare in <number>sing.</number> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylōnĭ-cum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, Publ. Syr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 35, 3</bibl>), <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">Babylonian coverings</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tapestry</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1026" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1026</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:2:26" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 34, 2, 26</bibl>; cf. Fest. s. v. solla, p. 298 Müll.: pelles, <hi rend="ital">coming from Babylonia</hi> (a tribute in the time of the emperors), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:39:4:16:section=7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 39, 4, 16, § 7</bibl>.—With reference to astrology (cf. II. B.): <cit><quote lang="la">doctrina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:726" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 726</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4772.8" n="D" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylōnĭensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = Babylonius, <hi rend="ital">Babylonian</hi> (only in Plaut.): miles, Truc. 1, 1, 66; 1, 2, 100; 2, 4, 38.—</sense><sense id="n4772.9" n="E" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Băbylō-nĭăcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = Babylonius, <hi rend="ital">Babylonian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">undae,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the Euphrates</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 4, 578</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
